newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Dlr needs more stamina to spring higher.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Dlr needs more stamina to spring higher.

text.p: After a week of solid gains, the dollar is likely to regroup before trying to resume its climb, analysts said on Friday.
But failure to break through key resistance levels vs. the mark and the yen could bring the bears back and lead to another round of dull consolidation, they added.
"Dollar/mark is in a topping out-process," said Scott Siller, analyst at MCM CurrencyWatch, while noting the "dollar just overshot 1.5165 marks" on Friday.
"It may take a week or so, the dollar may trickle higher, but not much higher before it retreats," Siller predicted.
In late Friday trade, the dollar was quoted at 1.5140/50 marks vs. 1.5122/27 at the open, and at 110.37/44 yen, virtually unchanged from the morning.

Late in the session, the dollar set its high for the day at 1.5173 marks -- just above the 1.5165 level that Siller said represents a 62-percent retracement of the decline between 1.5485 on May 28 and 1.4635 on July 31.
Still, the MCM CurrencyWatch analyst did not rule out the loss of intermediate support at 1.5090 marks, near term.
"We may dip through 1.5090 or even 1.5065/70, the low on September 11, and maybe get a bounce there," Siller added.
A bounce from the 1.5065-, 1.5090-mark area would allow the dollar to test strong resistance at 1.5180 and pave the way for a raid on the daunting 1.5240-mark level.
"There still is room for further improvement, but we are getting signs of a near-term top," Siller said. "At 1.5240, there is a lot of static resistance up there."
Dollar/yen looks to have retained more momentum and ready to march to a major resistance at 111.20.
"Dollar/yen could go to 111.20 yen," said Siller who sees the upside intact unless support at 109.85 is lost. "A move to 110 might be a buy, actually."

"Looking at the weekly studies, we have a strong bull channel, with projections to 113.50 yen or so, the last significant peak since we plunged to record lows (79.75 yen on April 19, 1995)," Siller added.
A dollar/yen rally could pull dollar/mark along -- though the two exchange rates do not always move in tandem.
"Dollar/mark and dollar/yen diverge occasionally. Dollar/yen could stay fairly flat and dollar/mark may go lower," Siller concluded.
